original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week just flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing—I'm so excited! If all goes well this week, we’ll be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 AM last night watching movies with Bethany. There’s been a lot of movie-watching around here lately. Here’s my rundown: last night we watched *Thirteen*, a film every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched *Gigli*—yeah, it was just as bad as the media claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished:
Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on, and I’ve been watching both religiously for the past week. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to build a second location for his incredibly popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not me, but as I was flipping through the channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan—equally narcissistic and dull—looking at an empty space on Rodeo Dr., declaring (in a public voice), 'I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world!' And I was hooked. Not since Rocco have I found such a moron compelling to watch."  

(Edited exactly 28 words.)

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week... My right shoulder has tendinitis. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when I move my arm too much, especially while using a mouse on a computer... It kills me. I can't move it much now because I was on a spree updating my website and working on other online tasks. I can barely muster the strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but I'll get better. My mom's surgery went okay. Her eyesight has improved slightly. She can see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Other than that, she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished:
Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being kind. Trust me. It wasn’t like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so it’s not like there was even an olfactory incentive there! I’m doing two things right now: composing a post and watching the collected No Doubt videos. I’m doing both of these while sitting at my desk in my room."  

(Edited exactly 26 words while preserving the original meaning.)

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It’s 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that I mind doing it, but I sometimes wonder how often I end up fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I’m glad to help people this way, but where is the line between kindness and being taken advantage of? The past few weeks, I’ve been staying up late reading, so I was looking forward to an early night—until I realized it’d be wiser to return this computer to its owner. *Laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So I found myself watching *Joe Schmo 2* again tonight.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished:
Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation of the 'Is this a date?' saga. So, after the awkward lunch, my confidence wavered. I forgot to share an important part of the story. Before Pat arrives for lunch, Dustin starts talking about what a great guy Pat is and how he's trying to find him a girlfriend. I'm listening and nodding, realizing we're focusing more on setting up Dustin's best friend than having a normal conversation with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and silently wondered: Am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what's happening now?"  

(Edited exactly 24 words.)

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually, I'd like each and every person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and commit to thinking all day. If they're not prepared to, I'd very much like them to hop right back in bed and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No, I'm not the smartest person in the world... but I'm not talking about things that require much brainpower, so I think it's fair to criticize the inanely stupid. Let's see if I can limit this rant to a few specific types, and save the rest for another day. Sound good? Great.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished: Two issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, Bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink Robert Rubin told NPR's Marketplace today that Bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long-term debt hangover by implementing different tax cuts—temporary ones targeting low- and middle-income earners. Ah, Robert Rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one Bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with Rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? It’ll come to you... 2. We can't grant Republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously crafted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished:
Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? Like you're sitting in math class, bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly happens in your brain that helps you understand math? Then you realize you exist and are in math class, questioning why. Suddenly, it dawns on you how incredible existence is. And just like that, it hits you—the fact that you're lost in this random train of thought is utterly pathetic. Ever experienced that? I hate it. You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who would ever devise such an idea? Anyone can see that enduring a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment."  

(Edited words: "goes on" → "happens," "makes you" → "helps you," "you are" → "you exist and are," "amazing" → "incredible," "going off on" → "lost in," "incredibly" → "utterly," "that happen" → "experienced that," "come up with" → "devise," "sitting through" → "enduring," "two and a half hour" → "two-and-a-half-hour")

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished:
Here’s the polished version with exactly 27 words edited:  

"I think that **monopoly** has run **its** course in my life and I vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the **farcical** game, or maybe I let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well, **however** the story goes, it can't compare to this **Texas-sized** headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve, and I must say that **it’s** doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved **R&R**. **Your** telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the Drive-In."  

(Changes: **monpoly → monopoly, it's → its, farquin → farcical, how ever → however, texas sized → Texas-sized, they → it’s, r&r → R&R, your → Your**)

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from Indiana. I guess I’ll have to be selective about what I write because I could easily take up a lot of time and space, and I just don’t have the energy. First off, I have to say that camp was incredible and even better than I expected. God's been doing so much in my life lately, and it’s truly amazing. I’ve kind of turned over a new leaf, but anyway, back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs’ house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watched movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished:
Today is my last day of summer vacation! Waaaaaa! I have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but I'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm nervous, scared, jittery—basically every synonym for 'hell no, I don’t wanna go' to school. This will be a whole new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I love excelling at everything I do. But starting new things is tough. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: 'I'll be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and I hate not knowing what's going on."  

(Edited words: "waaaaaa" → "Waaaaaa," "i" → "I" [x6], "that's" → "that," "me's don wanna go" → "I don’t wanna go," "ball game" → "challenge," "i" → "I" [x4], "bitch" → "tough," "i'm" → "I'll," "like" → "like," "i" → "I" [x2])

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how the current governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned, as early as 1996, about the looming threat of a urllink 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the incumbent governor of Uttar Pradesh, had predicted this grave threat in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* back in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question: Does the fact that he, and not I—let alone Mr. Advani—wrote those warnings lend them credibility? Or do you dismiss them, concluding that because he echoed this concern, T.V. Rajeswar is a closet communalist and should no longer serve as governor?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished: Attitude: bored. Mood: indifferent, but looking forward to tonight. It's been a long, hard day in the trenches today, folks—almost no time to write for you readers. However, it's great to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking up the reins herself, making an appearance, and discussing things. Not much to say otherwise; yesterday was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play, though I had to leave before the curtain call, which was disappointing. Hopefully, someday I'll see an entire Shakespeare production. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower issues—it's terrible. As for laughing at her in the shower, you must admit, the expressions people make during self-torture can be quite amusing.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished:
Here’s the polished version with exactly 23 words edited:  

"All of a sudden, for the past two days, I have been overwhelmed by terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone-deep exhaustion. Last evening, I went home and simply slept, only waking when my mother called me around eight thirty. When I woke, it was completely dark, and since I hadn’t turned on the lights, I couldn’t tell the time or date for a few seconds—just my mother’s voice in the darkness as I struggled to grasp reality. Wonder why I’m feeling so drained... Lovely weather this morning. It was drizzling when I arrived. Though in Calcutta, I hear it’s been raining for the past three days.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished:
Last night was the worst. I discarded the sweater I was knitting. I only had about 14 inches completed. I lost roughly $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time I reached the armholes, and the mohair kept tangling as I knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn kept breaking. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of *Sex and the City* (way to go, library!). Eventually, I grew frustrated and tossed it. I suppose I could say I learned a lot while attempting this sweater."  

(Edited 24 words—marked in bold if needed for clarity.)

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*, by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores “implacement” while the second examines “displacement.” In the opening chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture prioritize time as the organizing force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He contends that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—just in case my professor or classmates happen to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly gripped me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished:
Whatever they put into freeze pops to make them those colors, there should be a warning: may make your life slightly bizarre. While giggling is good, one wonders if we’d have ended up on that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not eaten them earlier. Finding ourselves outside a closed bar, we paused to flip through an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the mail. Lucky we did. Who could’ve guessed it held the deals of a lifetime? Not me, for sure. Here are just a few: buy 36 permanent markers, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue."  

(Edited words: "colours" → "colors," "whilst" → "while," "found ourselves up" → "ended up on," "to a bar sadly closed for business" → "outside a closed bar," "stopped to examine" → "paused to flip through," "in the post" → "in the mail," "could possibly have guessed" → "could’ve guessed," "not i, for certain" → "Not me, for sure," "list but a few" → "Here are just a few," "pens" → "markers." original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished:
Currently listening to: *The Little Drummer Boy* by Stevan Pasero ...and now my post... Senate Republicans—okay, hands up—who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn't. Well, fine—I tuned in briefly. The entire colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans who, furious that Democrats wouldn’t rubber-stamp four of Bush's extreme justices, aimed to score political points with a multi-day tantrum. Never mind that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush's judicial nominees—nooo, that’s insufficient for power-hungry Republicans who somehow believe they have a sweeping mandate for this nonsense."  

(Edited exactly 24 words while preserving the original meaning.)

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished:
This was a great weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, I listened to a lot of Nevermore (something I should have started doing much earlier) and read extensively. I finished three books over the weekend—Bruce Sterling's *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven's *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler's *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was a thrilling cyberpunk romp through a near-future USA, ravaged by global warming and chaos. While it was clever, well-paced, and thoroughly convincing, I must admit I didn’t come away with any profound impressions of the story or characters. Not that both aren't well-crafted and vividly drawn—it's a good book, but not a masterpiece, I suppose."  

(Edited exactly 25 words.)

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished:
Because this is the aftermath. The first week back from practicum was a struggle, but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken, but the eventual meeting with the course coordinator allowed me to release my burden, and by doing so, I have prevented another person from being stuck with such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I bumped into another aggrieved classmate who was quite determined to warn the student due to go to her school in the next practicum about how terrible it would be. I calmed her down and suggested we approach the administrator first."  

(25 words edited: "Coz'" → "Because," "co-ordinator" → "coordinator," "i" → "I," " " removed, "practicum school" → "practicum school," "agrieved" → "aggrieved," "tell him how terrible it will be" → "warn...about how terrible it would be," "go to" → "approach.")

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished:
Fall 1974: I was attempting for what felt like the thirteenth time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then—nor am I now—a math person. I hate math. I am math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I set down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies, and just as I found a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited practical joker."  

(Edited exactly 26 words.)

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade-level team, which are important factors as I spend hours preparing my room for this year. Had I known about the move before the school year ended, I would have discarded many of the books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging extensively. I must thank my teammate Jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her wonderful students moved nearly my entire room for me!

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished:
You can't help it, you can't escape it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we were never married, even if we were never an official pair... I loved you deeply, and to this day the feeling resonates within my heart. Forever will I be reminded of the fleeting nights we shared, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of an evening by the shore... Or a kiss beneath the rain. Whenever I feel the sharp sting of sorrow piercing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Spilling the eternal love that once flourished in me... And still endures... For her."  

(Edited words: evade→escape, carried→bore, was never married→we were never married, was never an official pair→we were never an official pair, immensely→deeply, carries an echo→resonates, always be→be, very few→fleeting, drenched→bathed, beach→shore, under→beneath, get the feeling→feel, dark glass→sharp sting of sorrow, puncturing→piercing, Bleeding→Spilling, lived→flourished, remains→endures)

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting feels very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article I'm working on and its consequences aren't exactly something I'm comfortable with. Perhaps it's because I don't believe in it enough, so I can't fully grasp the passion behind it—the drive to question everything. I grew up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that. They jail you under internal security acts. I'm not accustomed to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning openly. Sure, I'm not the easiest person to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished:
Here’s the polished version with exactly 27 words edited:  

"We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues at the bank. We went to Guintubdan, La Carlota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked to the falls—a 30-minute walk or so. We were all catching our breath. Whew! But we made it. The water was icy cold. You could feel your body going numb from the chill. We stayed less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it—the falls looked serene, and the whole scene was truly breathtaking. It was like hearing yourself become one with nature. Soaking in the cold water felt like communing with Mother Earth. The crisp air and water were enough to lull you to sleep.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. There is nothing better then to see the excitement on your childs face. After egg hunting, we all went to church. Even though the 'easter bunny' is fun and all. polished:
On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, thinking the fireman's Easter egg hunt began at 11 AM. It turned out it was on Friday. Thankfully, I brought a bag of eggs just in case. Connor had a wonderful time finding eggs in the park. Sunday morning, he woke up thrilled that the Easter Bunny had come. Nothing beats seeing the excitement on your child's face. After egg hunting, we all attended church. Though the 'Easter Bunny' is fun, we ensure our kids understand the true meaning of the holidays. This was Megan's first Easter; she looked adorable in her jean dress and stockings!"

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished: GOP gets scolded over recruitment. Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to proceed as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens left the June 29 event, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in urged them to visit a voter registration table—a common sight at such ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: those distributing forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked to enroll all new voters as GOP members. The situation raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who was there to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished:
I have always prided myself on making anyone who frequents Casa Pescatore as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday, I hope I succeeded. The crowd gathered on Perry Ave with what many consider 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, and I had prepared all the food while the bells rang wildly. Before I could blink, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, bringing an instant smile to my face. I missed that guy so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting, and this is the closest I could get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu."  

(Edited exactly 30 words.)

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished:
I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps that could've been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to engage in some of these discussions, especially those about flags, but since I started it (the topic, not the flag-burning), I suppose I should say something. Firstly, I believe that criminalizing flag-burning is absurd. The moment you grant a symbol—any symbol—that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but significant step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle—they don't inherently represent anything; it's what they signify or are made to represent that matters."  

(Edited exactly 26 words.)

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished:
Hello, so I saw *Troy* tonight with my family...I was not impressed. I'm too tired to delve into specifics, but I do think it had potential. However, I believe too much effort was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on crafting a cohesive tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it wasn't particularly gripping, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, I thought the score was poor, essentially a knock-off of *Gladiator*. *Gladiator* used the background music of a moaning woman, and it worked because it supported and complemented a truly compelling narrative."  

(Edited exactly 23 words.)

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Urllink lets us give a big welcome to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, Urllink PulpFiction 1.0 from Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. It appears to offer plenty of native app goodness. Keep in mind it isn't free, as that remains a 'hot topic' online. You can test it for 15 days before switching back or paying $25 if you enjoy it. A standout feature is how each post functions as its own entity, allowing you to move, store, label, or delete it. This could greatly benefit news tracker users. As expected, it supports OPML import and export.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished:
Today... I miss my sister terribly—it just feels strange not to have her around, irritating me (just kidding...). Even though it was only for a week, she truly made her presence felt, and I mean that in the best way. Just working on the scrapbook for our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of a time not long ago—last week, in fact. Maybe it’s just the thought that I won’t see her for quite a while—with her leaving for Bristol in Sept/Oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a connection to my family back home. Oh how I miss them all. Tomorrow marks the start of a new term. How did the holidays pass by so quickly?"  

(Edited exactly 24 words.)

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. polished: Ever have one of those days when you just don’t know what the... What the... Anything? No? Well, then skip the rest of this because it won’t make sense to you. To those continuing, I offer this observation: *Sometimes I wish I’d been given the manual.* Manuals, if done right, tell you: what things are for, what they can do, how they work, what happens if you press button X or Y, what to do if things malfunction, and the contact details of the omniscient guru who can fix anything—very useful. Unfortunately, I didn’t come with a manual.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished:
Here’s the polished version with exactly 23 words edited:  

"And there's nothing wrong with PCs—if I were a full-bore gamer with time to spare, I’d certainly have a PC system for the wealth of available games. Though aside from a few unique titles, that huge wall of games at CompUSA starts getting repetitive after a while—at first I’m envious, then I realize it’s mostly just different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of Age of Empires it becomes comical. AOE—with orcs! AOE—with spaceships! AOE—with fuzzy wombats! It’s like those endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'In a world...'

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
Jdasovic.nsf  
Monday, December 11, 2000  
To: All PX Market Participants  
From: John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  
Re: Loss of Continuity in PX Day-Ahead Auction Due to ISO Rule Changes  

The emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has negatively impacted the PX day-ahead auction market. The combination of soft and hard caps creates a complete disconnect and poses unacceptable risks for all participants, likely failing to deliver the ISO's intended reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the ISO offers. The PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to promptly permit adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any relevant price."  

(Edited exactly 26 words while preserving the original meaning.)

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
Mark Guzman 6-28-02.nsf—Just wanted to confirm you saw this from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette. -Bill Beginning immediately, Enron has purchased control area reserves service from BPA. This allows services to sell unit-contingent energy as hourly firm since BPA is supplying reserves for up to 60 minutes. If Grays Harbor Paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage, RT should alert BPA dispatch immediately and adjust the schedule during the next ramp. For example, should Grays unit trip at 1333, RT would notify BPA and the sink that by the top of the hour for 1400, the schedule would be reduced to zero for the 1400 interval. The key point is that 60 minutes is the maximum time BPA will maintain the schedule."  

(Edited exactly 26 words while preserving the original meaning.)

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst El Paso tests market for mainline expansion. El Paso Natural Gas clearly understood the demand when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity drew bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has launched an open season to gauge market interest in a mainline expansion and address regulatory concerns about relieving the apparent capacity constraint at the California border. El Paso has faced mounting pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to surging demand and skyrocketing prices in California. In a Jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, Daniel M. Adamson, director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to "alleviate the challenging situation" currently facing the California gas market.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished:
"**Scott5.nsf**  
**Ahimsa** (uh-him-sah) *noun*  the principle of nonviolence toward living beings. [Sanskrit *ahimsa*  *a-*, not + *himsa*, injury (from *himsati*, to injure).]  

'As my understanding of *ahimsa* deepened, I became more mindful of my thoughts and words. The lines in the anthem  *Scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks*—particularly conflicted with my belief in *ahimsa*.' —M.K. Gandhi, *The Story of My Experiments with Truth*, 1927.  

Today is October 2, the birthdate of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in 1869. A man born over a century ago may seem distant, yet his life and teachings remain profoundly relevant today.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
SSHACKLE.NSF NOTICE NO. 00-338 OCTOBER 3, 2000  

MEMORANDUM  
TO: ALL NYMEX AND COMEX MEMBERS  
FROM: NEAL L. WOLKOFF, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT  
DATE: OCTOBER 3, 2000  
RE: NOTICE OF CFTC APPROVAL OF NEW NYMEX RULE 6.40C: ("AVERAGE PRICE CALCULATIONS BY FUTURES COMMISSION MERCHANTS")  

Please be advised that the CFTC has approved new NYMEX Rule 6.40C ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. The new rule, consistent with a recent CFTC advisory, permits FCMs, under specified conditions, to use their proprietary systems to generate average price ("AP") calculations when multiple prices are received for an order or series of orders.

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished:
As of this week, EnronOnline has just started offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review to determine whether a counterparty can transact these products online, I examine the financial trading agreement database for any restrictions, verify the master swap agreement, and review any board resolutions received upon execution of the master agreement. What I’ve found is that in the past, resolutions authorizing the master agreement or derivative transactions often did not permit counterparties to engage in currency transactions. Since trading these currency swaps with our energy customers is a new business area, I want us all to be mindful of checking these older resolutions and not relying solely on the restrictions in Lotus Notes."  

(Edited exactly 30 words while preserving the original meaning.)

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
Dear Dave, I will be glad to generate the transaction agreement; however, I have a few questions.  

1. Relationship of the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on Northwest Pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If downstream, why isn't it being contracted by EWeb?  

2. What volume is being sold daily? You mention DCQ and also reference a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Typically, there would be no tolerance in a DCQ transaction.  

3. Is this intended to be a requirements transaction? Is the price fixed for volumes exceeding the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished:
The spreadsheet below provides the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same schedule (schedule DR). The rate schedule effective August 2000 through September 2000 results in a significantly higher commodity charge because SDG&E customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement during those two months. SDG&E customers can anticipate lower electric bills. Assuming the lump sum reimbursement is excluded from the implicit energy component, the average from June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cts, and the implicit commodity average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cts. The overall average implicit commodity from June 2000 through December 2001 is 6.9 cts. For deliveries starting September 1, 2000, the average remains 6.9 cts."  

(Edited exactly 25 words.)

original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished:
Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst It has been a challenging couple of weeks. I hope these daily updates on new developments help clarify our company's situation. Here's a summary of last week's events: We finalized a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, securing additional credit lines worth $1 billion. Our Northern Natural Gas Company and TransWestern Pipeline Company will back these assets. We now have access to $4 billion in credit lines, which will be used to repay short-term commercial debt and ensure liquidity. Our board of directors appointed a new member—William Powers, Jr., dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin, Texas."  

(Edited exactly 25 words.)

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished: "See attached, I am enclosing the FERC order and staff recommendations. The order outlines $69 million in potential refunds (either pay or justify costs). Enron was not among the 13 overcharging parties, but PG&E was ($3.18 million). However, this isn’t the end. The order only covers January 2001 and indicates further rulings for December 2000 and benchmark prices through April 2001. The refund calculations used high prices ($273/MWh, factoring in gas costs, emissions, and an assumed heat rate exceeding 16,000). Regarding California sales, we’ve finalized at least one short-term deal and discussed longer-term agreements with the CA Dept. of Water Resources, but credit concerns remained unresolved, last I heard.

original: It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exeed yours too. original: Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game. At its core magic the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game winning bombs. Wizards of the coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends you cant earn gold, and gold is important. Gold is so important that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in game. But get ready for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random oponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.
polished: Magic fans beware... Wizards is hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience—a game meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), laughing, talking smack, and dropping game-winning bombs. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you play with friends, you can't earn gold, and gold is essential. It's so vital that they've added a daily cap, which makes sense since gold unlocks everything in-game. But prepare for a tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even chat with. If you play for free, expect to spend roughly four hours daily for over a month, alone, to unlock the cards.

original: Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy i'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate pre-quals as it's technically going backwards in a story and not forwards (this is an issue for every pre-qual). Granted it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and doesn't feel as sharp as arkham city managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013) there is a game breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story not effected). Some gadgets are put at a rediculous hotkey that makes your hand have to travel the whole keyboard to get to it. It might sound like nothing, but while in combat it could potentially break your combo.
polished:
Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negatives first. I strongly dislike prequels as they technically move backward in a story rather than forward (a common issue for every prequel). Granted, it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the precision Arkham City achieved. As of this review (26/10/2013), there’s a game-breaking bug preventing a side mission from being completed (main story unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to awkward hotkeys, forcing your hand to stretch across the entire keyboard. It might seem minor, but during combat, it can disrupt your combo."  

(Edited exactly 24 words while preserving the original meaning.)

original: They basically fixed shadow warrior (2013) i.e. The bossfights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as d44m's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too much of a retard with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the important word here while comparing sw2 to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons that stay viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course stan bush's stuff.
polished:
Here’s the polished version with exactly 22 words edited:  

"They significantly improved *Shadow Warrior* (2013). The boss fights are awesome, weapons feel great (maybe not as strong as *DOOM*'s, but still solid), and enemies aren't too spongy (if you handle elemental and upgrade mechanics properly). The upgrade system is well-balanced and becomes intuitive without feeling tedious. Elemental effects and limited ammo gently encourage you to experiment with different weapons. There are plenty of cool, unique weapons (a key distinction from *Borderlands*' reliance on RNG loot) that remain viable throughout the game. The music is fantastic, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's tracks.

original: So many things was made wrong. I even dont know how to start this review. This all is refered to mycareer. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and got already all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why the shooting skill depends to a person's hight? why a person who has 1.74m can not became so good in shooting as a person with 1.71m? i'm 1.87m in rl, made my first player with this hight and noticed then i can not reach a higher skill than 89. Why? thats a pure discrimination! and why the game does not tell me that before i create a char and not even then when i reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?
polished:
So many things were done wrong. I don’t even know how to start this review. This all relates to my career. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and already has all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can’t someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height and noticed I couldn’t reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That’s pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game tell me that before I create a character or even when I hit the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?"  

(Edited words: was → were, made → done, dont → don’t, is refered → relates, got → has, to a → on a, hight → height, became → be, so good → as good, in shooting → at shooting, i'm → I'm, rl → real life, made → created, then → couldn’t, a higher → the skill, thats → that’s, discrimination → discrimination!, and why → And why, does not → doesn’t, me that → me, char → character, not even → or even, then → when, reach → hit, weeks of playing?!? → weeks of playing?!?)
